comments:
I'm using 3.0 M6

If you attempt to commit a java project that has a package with 'cvs' as part of the name (ie 
org.eclipse.cvs.core), the commit will fail.  I set up a simple test project with the package:

com.cvs.test.code

added a couple of java files, and then did a share project and commit.  Here is the details from the 
log file:

I'm guessing that there is a case-sensitivity issue here.  The net result is that I am unable to 
commit my production code to CVS.

google knows all and found the following "fix" for this problem:

http://homepage.mac.com/lgw4/iblog/C675550648/E871090033/

I might try it this weekend if I'm feeling VERY brave.

The Mac file system is not case sensitive (which is a suprise to me but test 
reveal that it is true. I guess the fix you mentioned corrects this) so the 
creation of the lower case cvs directory interferes with the creation of the 
CVS meta-data directory. You should rename your package. Convention is to use 
ccvs as the segment name (at least that's what we do;-). You should do this 
even if you make your Mac case sensitive as users of other OSes that are 
working on these packages will have the same problem.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 12345 ***

traces.message: A resource already exists on disk /Users/ bhunt/Downloads/eclipse/workspace/TestJav a/src/com/CVS.
